author: jonathan34562
body:
Please upvote this so I can answer the most common questions I am getting in one place.


1) How did I get to this point in my life?

I have a master degree in computer science and spent 8 years working as a programmer at lots of different companies.  Then I launched my own consulting company - quickly figured out that services work doesn't scale well - pivoted the business to a product startup and used the consulting to finance it.  All told, it took 20 years to get a really big exit - like net of over $200M.  
There is no shortcut that I know of - education, skills, experience,  lots of hard work for years and then luck.
Now I get to do whatever I like, I am typing this from a private jet on the wifi coming back from vacation... I know, wtf. I pinch myself too.


2) How can I invest like you?

Well. I have a lot of money so I can make risky bets.  I don't do options though, only stocks. I put $50k into GME on a whim at $65 and sold when it hit $350.  That was a laugh.  

But seriously, I invest in stocks that I feel like I know. I use HUBS - they are in a great space and really appealing to SMB. I see them as the most viable competitor to Salesforce - go look at Salesforce's market cap. Classic Clayton Christensen - you will be eaten from below.

I am not really much of an investor - just see things that make sense. I bought Amazon at $350 - should have put in more...

I typically invest in tech stocks because I feel like I understand the business.

My stock account is just my plaything. My real investing is much more structured and done with my wealth advisor at a large brokerage.

author: GeneEnvironmental925
body:
15 years.  Have been holding AAPL since 2006. My risk tolerance is above average but things don't feel that risky to me because I do my research. I like growth names but nothing crazy.  I have a large core of big tech. No China, though I was in NIO until earlier this year. I mostly buy-and-hold but sometimes the market dictates otherwise. Trading is for professionals, IMO.

AAPL AMD AMZN AVPT BARK CELH CRM CRWD DIS F GOOG MELI PINS PYPL SOFI UPST

This is my portfolio but I also have 20% split across three biotechs that I can't post in this subreddit. That's my high r/r, but I also don't feel like they're that risky because I know what I own.  

Read all the 10-K and 10-Q.  Listen to earnings calls and take notes.  Keep on top of national and world news. Look at options chains to get sentiment. Use Twitter for news and such. Learn how to read candlestick charts and spot reversals.  Don't panic sell. Don't listen to the noise online.

I broke $1.5m this morning.

author: abrownguyy
body:
Sure! I’m not an expert, nor do i think I am right above all else with how I do things. I’m not a technical analyst, and I’ve only been investing for about 4 years (I am 26). Everyone’s a genius in a bull market anyway so I’m sure a monkey could’ve performed similarly anyway - but you asked so I’ll share. 

1) only invest in companies you use and enjoy
2) only invest in companies who have forward thinking leaders with proven track records
3) only invest in companies who are building products/services for the future and don’t base your investment on historical performance 
4) don’t buy meme stocks and no one on the internet has the answers I learned this the hard way and am bag holding stocks below. 

I did not lose money on any meme stock. I made a lot off the video game store - this is probably part of the reason I got over confident and started breaking my own principles. 

I lost money on picks made by people on the internet ($FUBO, $CRLBF, $APPN, $FLGT) 

A good example of this would be SQ. I bought SQ back in 2017 when I first started investing. I’ve used their product at the barber, at the coffee shop up the road, at a farmer market. I thought to myself. “Wow, a mobile phone credit card reader for any small business, I only use card so this just made my life a whole lot easier - who made this?!?” 

Jack Dorsey obviously created twitter, and scaled one of the most popular social networks to billions of people and billions of dollars. I believed in him, and he’s a very…. “passionate” individual about the future. 

With the rise in SMB’s (I work for a tech company that serves SMB’s and realized how easy it is to start a biz now a days, I realized that this little mobile credit card processing company was only just getting started, and I bought a couple dozen shares of $SQ (wish I had more money back then). It’s my 2’d best performer behind $PENN (who fits this mold as well). 

Again, I know this is flawed, not-proven, and there are much better ways to go about investing. The 2020 bull run helped make me a ton of money and I’m very lucky in that sense that i invested in companies like $APPL, $SQ, $MSFT, $TSLA using these principles. Confirmation bias? 100%. But I’m gonna stick to it and hope it keeps working and gets me out of the hole I dug by taking the internet’s advice. 

A few stocks I’m currently interested in:
$CRM, $MSP, $S, $FTNT

author: interrobangbros
body:
WORK wasn’t moving because it was under agreement to be bought by Salesforce. The deal closed in late July and Slack stopped trading. It’s value was locked in last year when Salesforce announced they’d be buying it for $26.79 in cash and 0.0776 shares of CRM. That means it would only barely move as CRM moved. 

If your question is should you hold a company that has agreed to be bought, then it depends on the acquisition details and your motives. If your company is being bought for all cash or mostly cash, and you don’t think a bidding war is going to start, just sell now (unless it’s a new holding in a taxable brokerage and the deal close date will end up being >1 year after you bought). If it’s a mostly stock or all stock deal, ask yourself if you want to own shares in the new company. If yes, just hold. If no, sell now (same caveat about holding time as noted above).

author: 981flacht6
body:
Microsoft was already supported by BB Enterprise ID. Microsoft didn't choose them, BlackBerry is just leveraging Microsoft's product offerings into their own platform, which is meant to scale up and work with multiple services and companies using different connectors. 

You can setup BB Enterprise with AWS, Citrix, DocuSign, Dropbox, G Suite, Salesforce, ServiceNow, WebEx, Workday, Zendesk, Zscaler. These are all big companies that make a lot of enterprise tools that are used in large corporations everyday.

author: jonathan34562
body:
NextDoor isn't really about software. It is social, marketplace, ads, consumer, trendy.  More like Facebook.  Seems like mostly the "stay off my lawn" old folks users from my experience. 

Not something I really understand so I can't comment, sorry.

Not sure if HUBS or Salesforce will get to different numbers first but I think Salesforce will have a hard time serving the lower end of the market and that is where HUBS will grow. And then once big enough and sophisticated enough, then HUBS will challenge Salesforce in the enterprise.  My startup did this too in a different market. It is Clayton Christensen stuff - eaten from below...

author: Philosophfries
body:
Again, very dramatic analysis for someone who doesn’t know his situation. It took me all of 10 seconds to click on OP’s profile, click comments, and see he initiated these positions on the 20th, just a few days ago. So yeah, I’d say ~5% returns in a few days is probably fine. But who knows where things will go.

> He will do worse as time moves on.

Hard disagree. With a broad portfolio of largely successful businesses, the long term is more favorable than the short term for this investor. That’s just how the market has worked. I’d be more inclined to agree with you if his portfolio was full of penny stocks and high risk assets.

> He is not mostly invested in blue chips.

I said blue chips and successful businesses. You just can’t read or didn’t bother to. Google, Amazon, salesforce, amd, capital one, etc. These aren’t failing companies.

Like I stated before, the only thing of value that you contributed is advocating for index funds. If OP is going to invest in a bunch of big companies anyways, might as well save time and just throw it into a large index fund with a low expense ratio.

author: BannerlordAdmirer
body:
Most of them except MSFT are actually still 10% or more off their ATHs. AAPL, V, DIS all dropped 4-5%. DIS and AAPL dropped 5% in one day, earlier this week. CRM was at 252 and Paypal was 265 last week. At what point is a dip good enough? 

Most of the large caps move in correlation with each other and the market. So outside of earnings, if you decide to pass on a dip for one or wait to see if it gets worse, and if they reverse, you miss it for all of them.  

FB or QCOM are still somewhat close to their recent lows. If we're looking at large cap deals, those could be good. A lot of the midcaps though already moved 15%+ in the last two-three weeks. 

If ASTS goes down that would be my pick for a riskier gamble. 

I think heading into October/November, the debt ceiling news cycle will start and we'll have more chances to enter/add.

author: BannerlordAdmirer
body:

I might pick up some PYPL as well. Maybe another two rounds of buying powder left, so hopefully these are just convenience dips and not the start of a bear market.

body:

Jobs have been an excel database analyst and nothing too heavy with coding yet so I’ve never done a code-heavy job.

author: mrponcho99

author: moneylivelaugh
body: Probably not. I’ve noticed Saleforce has bolstered up their sales efforts on acquiring smaller customers. I think converting hubspot customers over to saleforce is a tough sell. The actual hubspot solution is better than salesforces. The thing salesforce did well was create a platform out of their CRM, their actual tech is pretty lame built on APEX code and Oracle databases, their secrete sauce is the ability for other companies to monetize within their platform through building apps that solve problem, it further entrenches the reliance of that particular company and saleforce.com

author: GuyBelowMeDoesntLift
body:
What google and apple have done is made themselves integral to the process of making money, to the point where you have to use (usually multiple) google and apple products to do business. You can swap off them, but you won’t because they’re superior products and everyone else uses them. Not terribly hard to see how a monopoly like that will be able to reinforce itself for at least the next decade.

Companies like them, microsoft, salesforce will go up even though it’s mcdonald’s and starbucks that are enjoying the business consolidation. You’re right that it has to do with all the cheap money flying around, which helps everyone’s bottom line, but fundamentally big business is a very good investment to be in. 

It helps that if any one business in the S&P starts failing, they just kick it out and put the next-best one in. It’s guaranteed to be the best possible sample from the overall picture of business in this country, and at any rate is not worth betting against
